Demand response (DR) is an effective method for achieving energy flexibility. Preheating can store a certain amount of energy in the building while simultaneously reducing the heat load. The energy flexibility of a building during the heating season mainly depends on the types of DR events, the thermal performance of the building envelope, and weather conditions. Analyzing the impact of these factors on the preheating performance and exploring their interactions can reveal the potential for energy flexibility. This study proposes a simulation-based method to evaluate the energy flexibility of a residential building in Kitakyushu, Japan from the perspectives of energy efficiency, load and energy reduction. Rule-based control strategies are applied to heating, ventilation, and air conditioning systems. The results show that compared to preheating temperature of 24 °C, high insulation building at 25 °C achieves energy efficiency improvement of 3.5%–14.8% and load reduction increase of 1.6%–22.2%. Compared to low insulation building, preheating at 25 °C for 1 h increases energy efficiency in high insulation building by 6.2%–10.3%, with corresponding load reduction increase of 1.0%–19.1%. Extending the preheating duration improves load reduction but leads to heat loss. Preheating during heating system startup should be avoided as it produces the worst energy flexibility. Moreover, statistical analysis identifies key indicators for energy reduction: the inside surface temperature of the exterior wall (Pearson correlation coefficient = 0.820, standard regression coefficient = 0.924), followed by global horizontal radiation and building insulation performance. The highest energy consumer countries, including China, the United States, Russia and Japan, account for the majority of the global energy consumption [2]. With the ongoing urbanization in developing countries, the global energy consumption of buildings will continue to increase. Therefore, to achieve the goal of net-zero emissions, the building sector needs to move more quickly towards an energy-efficient transformation. To achieve energy transformation, supply–demand balance in the power grid is required [3]. The traditional method of achieving this balance is mainly via the supply side, where the power grid limits the generation rate or integrates backup equipment into the network—a method known as “supply follows demand” [4]. However, as the proportion of renewable energy sources continues to increase, the energy supply from the supply side often comes to depend on uncertain factors such as weather, which require flexibly adjusting energy usage at the demand side [5]. The building equipment adjusts power demand flexibly according to power grid supply or price signals, and this adjustment approach on the demand side is known as demand response (DR) [6,7], which can achieve energy flexibility. The concept of energy-flexible buildings in accordance with IEA EBC Annex 67 [8] has been proposed, which involves adjusting building energy use flexibly to meet building energy demands based on local climate conditions, user needs, and energy network constraints. Energy flexible buildings allow for DR management. DR in buildings can decrease energy demand and enable the buildings to serve as a grid resource for peak shaving and valley filling. DR control strategies include power regulation of building electrical equipment as well as using batteries, thermal storage devices, and building envelope structures for direct or passive energy storage [9–11]. The building envelope is an important element that separates indoor and outdoor heat exchange, and its good insulation properties enable energy storage, thus temporarily reducing building load. Therefore, building energy demand can be shifted over time [12]. Currently, heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems are commonly used as control devices to store energy in buildings by utilizing the insulation properties of the building envelope, which allows preheating or precooling during nonpeak periods while maintaining indoor thermal comfort [13,14]. This energy storage method is also known as passive thermal storage [15]. It helps not only shift peak power [10,12], but also alleviate the pressure on physical energy storage [16]. 1.2 Quantification of building energy flexibility The potential for building energy flexibility is typically evaluated by quantifying building energy consumption, electricity cost, thermal energy storage efficiency, flexibility duration, and comfort [17,18]. In addition, it is affected by the thermal performance of building envelope structures [19]; local weather conditions, including diurnal and seasonal variations and climatic zone differences [20,21]; and DR events by building occupants, such as HVAC system control, household appliance operation control, and lighting system control [22]. To quantify and compare the potential of using a building envelope to achieve energy flexibility, previous studies have proposed indicators based on the objectives. Energy flexibility indicators makes DR management technologies more specific. However, some studies have only considered a single perspective. For example, Bandera et al. [23] and Bashir et al. [24] quantified the DR ability to consume photovoltaic power but ignored load shifting. Johra et al. [19] and Finck et al. [25] defined real-time electricity prices on the user side and quantified the ability to transfer electricity consumption from peak to off-peak periods by DR. Multiple indicators are needed to measure building energy flexibility comprehensively. Zhang et al. [26] quantified the energy flexibility of heating systems based on indicators such as flexible energy, flexible energy efficiency, and maximum flexible power to minimize energy costs without violating thermal comfort conditions. Zhou et al. [27] quantified the energy flexibility of buildings using renewable energy based on indicators such as renewable electricity surplus period, renewable electricity shortage period, and flexible power. Reynders et al. [28] quantified the energy flexibility of buildings with passive thermal storage according to storage capacity, storage efficiency, and power shifting capability. In summary, multiple quantification indicators allow for a holistic assessment of building energy flexibility from different perspectives. In addition, analyzing the factors affecting energy flexibility is important, which will clarify the energy flexibility potential. The building envelope contributes to energy flexibility, as the energy required by the building can be shifted and shed without jeopardizing indoor comfort. Previous research has focused on the impact of typical buildings on energy flexibility, including the age of the building [29], building type [28], and insulation performance [13,22]. Overall, these studies focused on the thermal performance of the building envelope, such as building thermal mass and building insulation performance. Lu et al. [30] studied the influence of the thermal mass of the envelope structure on building energy flexibility during the cooling season. They found that a larger thermal mass was more helpful for reducing peak loads and improving the energy efficiency of passive energy storage. Wei et al. [31] introduced dynamic electricity prices to evaluate the ability of the exterior wall to shift energy consumption from high-price periods to low-price periods. They found that the lower the thermal conductivity of the exterior wall is, the larger the reduction in electricity costs and the shorter the preheating duration during low-price periods. The outdoor environment affects the indoor load, so buildings require an appropriate DR event for different weather conditions to achieve energy flexibility [32]. In the construction industry, the design of passive houses not only consider good thermal insulation performance, but also make use of heat gain from solar energy. Foteinaki et al. [22] studied detached houses and apartment buildings to regulate the setting temperature of HVAC within the range of human comfort and quantified the increase or decrease in building load during the regulation period. The study demonstrated that energy flexibility is highly correlated with solar radiation and illustrates the importance of the insulation performance of the building envelope. Vivian et al. [29] studied the effect of weather conditions on building energy flexibility and analyzed the relationship among thermal discomfort, passive thermal storage, and energy efficiency during winter and summer. The study demonstrated that a different diurnal distribution of solar radiation in different months of summer leads to a change in energy flexibility, resulting in changes in optimal HVAC control strategy. The control strategies of DR events can be classified into rule-based control (RBC) and model predictive control (MPC). RBC methods commonly involve controlling the HVAC system within the comfort range of occupants, and the control duration can vary from a few seconds to 6 h [29,30,33]. MPC is frequently employed for optimizing control problems, where the optimal control strategy relies on the optimization objective. A common example is the optimal control of indoor appliances to minimize power consumption [34]. Although MPC can achieve optimal energy flexibility, it requires precise and complex predictive models [25,35]. RBC can satisfy certain optimization objectives and offer strong interpretability for quickly determining energy flexibility [36], thus providing a comprehensive comparison of the factors influencing energy flexibility. Although progress in evaluating energy flexibility has been made, some areas require further investigation, particularly in determining the factors influencing energy flexibility. Specifically, the inverse relationship between the U-value and thermal mass, impact of outdoor weather conditions, and the need for a quantitative ranking of influential factors warrants further examination. First, scholars have investigated the impact of the U-value and thermal mass on energy flexibility. However, an inverse relationship exists between the U-value and thermal mass, as variations in the thermal mass may lead to changes in the U-value. Therefore, it is crucial to convert them into singular variables for analysis. Second, outdoor weather conditions crucially affect energy flexibility. Most current studies have analyzed several specific typical days to quickly determine the impact of outdoor weather conditions, but the analysis is not conducive for drawing general conclusions. Finally, a quantitative ranking of the factors that affect energy flexibility is lacking in the literature, making it impossible to identify the key factors affecting energy flexibility. Therefore, to elucidate the potential of building energy flexibility, it is necessary to comprehensively consider the impact of the building envelope, outdoor weather conditions, and DR events and explore their interactions. 1.3 Contributions of this research This work aims to study the application of preheating control strategies in residential buildings to achieve energy flexibility. The energy flexibility indicators are proposed to evaluate the potential of energy flexibility. Meanwhile, the impact of DR events, the thermal performance of the building envelope, and weather conditions on energy flexibility is analyzed, and their interactions are explored. Residential buildings are classified based on the thermal performance of their envelopes. Rule-based control strategies are adopted for DR events, considering the impact of preheating start time and outdoor weather on energy flexibility. Finally, the factors affecting energy reduction are ranked by statistical analysis. The paper makes the following contributions: (1) A simulation-based method is established to evaluate building energy flexibility. Energy flexibility indicators are proposed to quantify energy flexibility from the perspectives of energy efficiency, load and energy reduction. (2) The impact of DR events, thermal performance of building envelopes, and weather conditions on energy flexibility is analyzed. Their interactions are explored to determine the key impact. (3) Statistical analysis is utilized to determine the ranking of the factors affecting energy reduction. A correlation analysis is performed, and the ranking of the factors is then assessed using standard regression coefficients (Beta). The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Fig. 1 illustrates the process of quantifying and analyzing building energy flexibility in this study. Subsection 2.1 introduces preheating control strategies, and subsection 2.2 discusses the indicators for quantifying energy flexibility. 2.1 Control strategy of preheating Energy flexibility refers to the capacity of a building to deviate from its original control strategy after DR is implemented on the user side [37]. HVAC systems are instrumental in achieving energy flexibility in buildings. In winter, good insulation properties of the building envelope are necessary for HVAC systems to be preheated within the comfort range. Maintaining indoor temperatures within the range of 23 ± 2 °C can cover 80% of the thermal comfort zone [38]. Therefore, the indoor setting temperature will be maintained within this range for thermal comfort. In this study, a simulation method based on two types of control strategy cases was used to quantify the energy flexibility of a residential building, as depicted in Fig. 2 . The reference case and the flexibility case were compared, with the HVAC system operating from 08:00 to 00:00 the following day. To systematically analyze the thermal performance, the buildings were initially categorized into three groups based on the thermal mass of their envelope: light, medium, and heavy structures. Subsections 5.1 and 5.2 analyze the impacts of different types of buildings under DR events from the perspective of energy efficiency and load/energy reduction, respectively. 5.1 Impact of building cases on energy efficiency under DR events According to the control strategy in Table 5, nine buildings were preheated in January at setting temperatures of 24 °C/25 °C and preheating intervals ranging from 20 to 180 min every 20 min; the analysis results of η are shown in Fig. 7 . Further, the preheating control strategy in Table 6 was utilized to analyze energy flexibility by applying preheating for 1 h at 25 °C at different start times. The η value of different building cases was compared, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . 5.1.1 Impact of control strategies on η For all buildings, η gradually decreased with increasing duration at different preheating setting temperatures, and the rate of this decrease fell as the preheating duration increased. As shown in Fig. 7, compared with the case of preheating for 20 min, a significant decrease in η occurs when preheating is applied for 40 min, after which the rate of this decrease gradually falls, and the difference in η between preheating for 160 min and preheating for 180 min is minimal. This is attributable to the heat loss of the building envelope increasing when the preheating duration is extended. A shorter preheating duration results in lower heat loss, and the energy stored in the building following preheating can effectively reduce the heat load provided by the heating system during the subsequent period. Moreover, as preheat time increases, although the heat loss gradually increases, it tends to stabilize, resulting in a lower rate of decrease in η . The results demonstrate that a preheating setting temperature of 25 °C leads to higher η for the same building, indicating that increasing the setting temperature to the upper comfort limit can improve η . For example, House 3.0 shows a 3.5%–14.8% increase in η when preheated to 25 °C compared to 24 °C. In addition, when the setting temperature was 25 °C and the preheating duration was 20 min, the buildings with high insulation performance (House 1.0, House 2.0, and House 3.0) exhibited an η value near 1. Therefore, a higher preheating temperature and shorter preheating duration will contribute to higher η . 5.1.2 Impact of thermal performance of the buildings on η Under the same control strategy, the U-value of the building envelope has a more significant impact on η compared to thermal mass. For buildings under the same category of thermal mass, such as House 3.0, House 3.1, and House 3.2 shown in Fig. 7(c), at the same preheating setting temperature (25 °C), the η of House 3.0 is improved by 6.2%–10.3% compared to House 3.2. Meanwhile, buildings with the same insulation performance and different categories of thermal mass exhibit similar η values under the same preheating setting temperature. For example, at 24 °C preheating, the η values for buildings with high insulation performance, namely House 1.0, House 2.0, and House 3.0 were 0.63, 0.64, and 0.63, respectively, when the preheating duration was 180 min. Furthermore, the results were similar for buildings with medium insulation performance (House 1.1, House 2.1, and House 3.1) as well as buildings with low insulation performance (House 1.2, House 2.2, and House 3.2). Therefore, to improve η , the insulation performance of the building should be improved. 5.1.3 Comparison of the impact of control strategies and building thermal performance on η For the same building, preheating at 25 °C can increase the η value. In addition, for all buildings, when the preheating duration was 20 min, 40 min, and 60 min, η was higher when the preheating setting temperature was 25 °C than when it was 24 °C. However, as the preheating duration increased, the advantage of preheating at 25 °C gradually disappeared for buildings with low insulation performance (House 1.2, House 2.2, and House 3.2). Taking House 1.2 with a preheating setting temperature of 25 °C and House 1.0 with a preheating setting temperature of 24 °C as examples, it can be found that House 1.2 preheated at 25 °C produced a higher η when the preheating duration was less than or equal to 60 min. However, as the preheating duration continues to increased, η gradually dropped below that of House 1.0 preheated at 24 °C, and at a preheating duration of 180 min, η was significantly lower than that of House 1.0 preheated at 24 °C. Therefore, the preheating setting temperature has an important effect on η when the preheating duration is short. As the preheating duration increases, the impact of the preheating setting temperature on η gradually weakens; ultimately η becomes mainly dependent on the insulation performance of the building. 5.1.4 Impact of different start times on η for the same control strategy As shown in Fig. 8, preheating at 08:00 results in the worst η for all buildings. This is attributable to the HVAC system starting to operate at 08:00, whereas preheating is used for heating indoor air and building envelopes, resulting in less excess heat. In contrast, preheating at other times leads to a higher η . For buildings with high (House 1.0, House 2.0, and House 3.0) and medium insulation performance (House 1.1, House 2.1, and House 3.1), preheating at 09:00 can achieve the highest η . However, buildings with low insulation performance can achieve a higher η later. Therefore, preheating during HVAC system startup should be avoided to achieve better performance. Buildings with different insulation performances exhibit varying trends in η at different start times, as depicted in Fig. 8. Except for cases when preheating starts at 08:00, the better the insulation performance of the building envelope, the greater the change in η during the day. Taking House 3.2 as an example, when preheating began at 10:00, η was 0.732, whereas it was 0.715 when preheating began at 16:00, representing a decrease in η of 2.3%. η for House 3.1 was 0.768 when preheating started at 09:00, whereas it was 0.746 when preheating started at 16:00, representing a 2.9% decrease. η for House 3.0 was 0.806 when preheating started at 09:00, whereas it was 0.751 when preheating started at 14:00, representing a 6.8% decrease. Therefore, the better the insulation performance of the building, the more significant the effect of start time on η . In addition, buildings with high insulation performance should be selected for preheating at the appropriate time to achieve energy flexibility. 5.2 Impact of building cases on load/energy reduction under DR events Fig. 9 shows the effect of building cases on load reduction under different control strategies in January when the preheating control strategy in Table 5 is adopted. First, a residential building model was established, and the accuracy of the building model was validated. To investigate the impact of the thermal performance of the building envelope on energy flexibility, the building envelope was modified in the original model, resulting in nine different buildings. Thereafter, two flexibility strategies were defined based on RBC to explore the impact of different DR events on energy flexibility. Additionally, weather conditions play a significant role in energy reduction. To compare the factors that influence energy reduction, a multiple linear regression model was established. Beta was used to analyze the influence ranking. The main conclusions are as follows: (1) From the perspective of DR events, preheating can achieve short-term energy flexibility during the heating season. Raising the preheating setting temperature to the upper limit of human thermal comfort (25 °C) can provide more energy flexibility for the building. Although longer preheating duration is conducive to reducing heat load, it will reduce energy efficiency and cause heat loss. Further, avoiding preheating during HVAC system startup is recommended as it results in the worst energy flexibility. (2) From the perspective of building thermal performance, improving the insulation performance of the building is more beneficial for achieving a higher energy efficiency, load and energy reduction than the building thermal mass. Moreover, in comparing the impact of DR events and building thermal performance on energy flexibility, buildings with low thermal insulation performance can achieve better energy flexibility when preheated at a higher temperature. Therefore, choosing an appropriate control strategy is crucial. (3) The inside surface temperature of exterior wall can be used as a major indicator for energy reduction, followed by global horizontal radiation and building insulation performance. To achieve energy reduction, it is crucial to ensure that the building stores sufficient heat and fully exploits the weather conditions to preheat the building during periods of high solar radiation. Finally, the insulation performance of the building should be improved. 6.2 Future work Future work will focus on the following areas: First, this study only considered the winter heating season but ignored the cooling scenario, so future work will expand the simulation scenarios to analyze the year-round situation. Second, this study analyzed impact of building thermal performance; However, the impact of envelope absorptivity and reflectivity on energy flexibility is neglected. Consequently, future work will include a wider range of building thermal performance for analysis. Third, the impact of the outdoor environment on energy flexibility was only investigated in one specific region, limiting the generalizability of the results to other climates. To address this limitation, future research will consider multiple climatic regions to obtain more universal conclusions. coredata.dc:description: Demand response (DR) is an effective method for achieving energy flexibility. Preheating can store a certain amount of energy in the building while simultaneously reducing the heat load. The energy flexibility of a building during the heating season mainly depends on the types of DR events, the thermal performance of the building envelope, and weather conditions. Analyzing the impact of these factors on the preheating performance and exploring their interactions can reveal the potential for energy flexibility. This study proposes a simulation-based method to evaluate the energy flexibility of a residential building in Kitakyushu, Japan from the perspectives of energy efficiency, load and energy reduction. Rule-based control strategies are applied to heating, ventilation, and air conditioning systems. The results show that compared to preheating temperature of 24 °C, high insulation building at 25 °C achieves energy efficiency improvement of 3.5%–14.8% and load reduction increase of 1.6%–22.2%. Compared to low insulation building, preheating at 25 °C for 1 h increases energy efficiency in high insulation building by 6.2%–10.3%, with corresponding load reduction increase of 1.0%–19.1%. Extending the preheating duration improves load reduction but leads to heat loss. Preheating during heating system startup should be avoided as it produces the worst energy flexibility. Moreover, statistical analysis identifies key indicators for energy reduction: the inside surface temperature of the exterior wall (Pearson correlation coefficient = 0.820, standard regression coefficient = 0.924), followed by global horizontal radiation and building insulation performance.
coredata.dc:title: Potential quantification and impact factors analysis of energy flexibility in residential buildings with preheating control strategies
